dublin_core.dcvalue: Radiographs on a viewing box were photographed at a remote hospital in South Africa using a digital camera with a resolution of 1024 x 768 pixels at 24 bit colour depth The resultant images were stored in JPEG format and transmitted as email attachments to be read on a PC monitor by radiologists in Durban and Cape Town Twenty seven images were received of which 23 were of diagnostic quality 85 The mean file size was 120 kByte For quality control purposes 100 chest radiographs were photographed at a base hospital and read by a radiologist blinded to the diagnosis In this study 96 images were of diagnostic quality 96 and the correct diagnosis was made in 90 cases 94 Incorrect readings were made in six cases 6 small pulmonary nodules less than 1 cm in diameter were missed in five cases and in one case early apical tuberculosis was missed Digital camera technology permits simple inexpensive telemedicine Limited spatial resolution is a concern when reading chest images with small pulmonary nodules and infiltrates
A simple telemedicine system using a digital camera.
